title: Safety to Disagree
description: Explore how safe it feels to have different opinions

questions.text: I can share a different opinion without worrying it will damage us.

therapeutic.rationale: Healthy relationships have room for disagreement. When sharing a different opinion feels dangerous, partners often silence themselves, which leads to distance and resentment over time.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner fears disagreement will cause damage, explore what happens when they disagree. Does the other partner withdraw? Escalate? Understanding the pattern helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared safety to disagree creates space for both partners to be authentic.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens between you when you share different opinions?

questions.text: My partner seems genuinely interested in my perspective, even when they disagree.

therapeutic.rationale: Interest in your partner's perspective—even during disagreement—communicates respect. When partners stop being curious about each other's views, conflicts become about winning rather than understanding.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel interest in their perspective, explore how the other shows (or fails to show) curiosity during disagreements.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual curiosity about each other's perspectives creates productive disagreements.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner show interest in your perspective during disagreements?

questions.text: Disagreements don't make me question whether we're okay.

therapeutic.rationale: When disagreements trigger relationship anxiety—'Does this mean we're not right for each other?'—even minor conflicts become threatening. Secure couples can disagree without doubting their foundation.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If disagreements trigger relationship doubt for one partner, explore what would help them feel more secure. Sometimes explicit reassurance during conflict helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence that disagreements don't threaten the relationship creates security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do disagreements ever make you question your relationship? What triggers that?

questions.text: I can be honest about what I think without fear of my partner's reaction.

therapeutic.rationale: Fear of your partner's reaction leads to walking on eggshells. When you can be honest without bracing for a negative response, authentic communication becomes possible.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner fears reactions, explore what reactions they're anticipating. Anger? Withdrawal? Hurt? The other partner needs to understand how their responses land.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual freedom from fear of reactions creates open, honest communication.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What reactions from your partner do you find yourself trying to avoid?

questions.text: Our relationship feels strong enough to handle differences.

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence that your relationship can handle differences reflects secure attachment. This confidence allows partners to bring up difficult topics rather than avoiding them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel the relationship can handle differences, explore what would build that confidence. Successful navigation of past conflicts? Reassurance?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in your relationship's strength creates willingness to address real issues.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What differences have you navigated successfully? What made that possible?
